simone

One of the most dangerous things an African woman can do is become pregnant. So, along with the winner of my contest for college students, Paul Bowers, I have been visiting the forlorn hospitals here in West Africa. According to the World Health Organization, Sierra Leone has the highest maternal mortality in the world, and in several African countries, 1 woman in 10 ends up dying in childbirth.
 
 It's pretty clear that if men were dying at these rates, the United Nations Security Council would be holding urgent consultations, and a country such as this would appoint a minister of paternal mortality. Yet half-a-million women die annually from complications related to pregnancy or childbirth without attracting much interest because the victims are typically among the most voiceless people in the world: impoverished, rural, uneducated and female.

 http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/17/opinion/17kristof.html
 
 But women, being less than human, are extremely expendable.
 
 Right, Cybererratus?

I've been fighting this seemingly default "marriage" between pro-life views and religion for nearly 20 years now. One of my favorite ways to make people reconsider their prejudices is to ask "do your really need god or faith or religion in your life to recognize the faces, fingers and toes (or any other human attributes) of a "born" child?" If not,... "why do you need God or faith or religion to recognize those SAME attributes in a child that is still in the womb?"

 Perhaps fingers and toes make a person in your mind, but not in the minds of most on the pro-choice side. For many of us, it is the mind that makes a person. In that case, we recognize it where it actually exists or might exist - in both born humans and in late term fetuses. 
 
 Also, given that the great majority of people in the US espouse some form of religion or spirituality, that means that the majority of pro-choice supporters are religious. Indeed, nearly half of Catholics are pro-choice - not generally considered a liberal religion. So, the idea in the minds of many pro-life supporters that those on the pro-choice side are atheists or generally anti-religion is also completely false. There is no such marriage of pro-choice and atheistic beliefs. 
 
I'm so tired of fighting the ignorance and denials of the left, I'm about done with it. As soon as you make a compelling point to ANY of them, they run, change the subject, attack you personally or do anything but acknowledge you've made a point.

 Your point here would be stronger if you yourself did not constantly engage in the same tactics that you accuse others of doing. I have answered nearly all of the points you ever made to me (I might have missed one or two during your period of multiple replies). You, however, have very often engaged in the very behavior toward me that you accuse those on the pro-choice side of engaging in.

Indeed, nearly half of Catholics are pro-choice

 Not necessarily, 
 Poll Finds Majority of Catholics Pro-Life on Abortion, Favor Parental Notification

Another opinion

Not necessarily, 
 Poll Finds Majority of Catholics Pro-Life on Abortion, Favor Parental Notification
 Most of the pro-choice Catholics are Catholic-in-name-only. They don't practice the religion in other words. These are the Catholics who either don't go to mass ever or only go Christmas/Easter.

 Yes, I could well imagine that those who are more strongly religious would statistically tend to be more likely to be pro-life. However, there are large numbers of Americans that are religious without being of the sort that attend mass or service regularly - including Catholics. However, just because they do not attend mass or service regularly does not mean that one can claim that they are either atheists or anti-religion. The very fact that they claim allegiance to a particular religion means that they do believe in many or most of that religion's tenets. The fact that they do not attend mass or service as frequently might simply mean that their beliefs may not be as strongly held, or they may not feel as much need to follow religious authorities, rituals or communities.
 
 Either way, my main point was that being pro-choice does not automatically translate into being anti-religion. There is very significant overlap between people who espouse religious beliefs and those that espouse pro-choice views. Certainly, if one takes the extremes of the strongly religious vs atheists, then the strongly religious will be far more likely to be pro-life whereas atheists will be far more likely to be pro-choice. However, those extremes do not consitute the majority of the US population - whose religious views and abortion issue affiliations are far more mixed.
